description: From Middle English cronk, cranke, from Old English cranc, from Proto-West Germanic *krank, from Proto-Germanic *krangaz, *krankaz (“bent; weak”).
Cognate with German krank (“sick”), Dutch krank (“sick”).

entries.meaning: (slang) Strange, weird, odd.
Sick; unwell.
examples: Synonym: infirm

entries.meaning: (nautical, of a ship) Liable to capsize because of poorly stowed cargo or insufficient ballast.
examples: This ship is so crank and walty
I fear our grave she will be!

entries.meaning: Full of spirit; brisk; lively; sprightly; overconfident; opinionated.
examples: He who was a little before bedred […] was now cranke and lustie.

definitionGroups.group: A bent piece of an axle or shaft, or an attached arm perpendicular, or nearly so, to the end of a shaft or wheel, used to impart a rotation to a wheel or other mechanical device; also used to change circular into reciprocating motion, or reciprocating into circular motion.

entries.meaning: Clipping of crankshaft.
The act of converting power into motion, by turning a crankshaft.
examples: Yes, a crank was all it needed to start.
Give it a forceful crank.

entries.meaning: (archaic) Any bend, turn, or winding, as of a passage.
examples: So many turning cranks these have, so many crooks.

entries.meaning: (informal) An ill-tempered or nasty person.
examples: Billy-Bob is a nasty old crank! He chased my cat away.

entries.meaning: A twist or turn of the mind; caprice; whim;
a fit of temper or passion.
(informal, Britain, dated in US) A person who is considered strange or odd by others. They may behave in unconventional ways.
examples: Synonyms: kook, odd duck, weirdo, (US) crackpot; see also Thesaurus:strange person
John is a crank because he talks to himself.

entries.meaning: (archaic, baseball, slang, 1800s) A baseball fan.
(informal) An amateur in science or other technical subjects who persistently advocates flawed theories
examples: That crank next door thinks he’s created cold fusion in his garage.

entries.meaning: (US, slang) Synonym of methamphetamine.
examples: Danny got abscesses from shooting all that bathtub crank.

entries.meaning: (rare) A twist or turn in speech; word play consisting in a change of the form or meaning of a word.
(obsolete) A sick person; an invalid.
(slang) The penis.
examples: Synonyms: cock, dick; see also Thesaurus:penis

verbs.description: crank (third-person singular simple present cranks, present participle cranking, simple past and past participle cranked)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To turn by means of a crank.
examples: Motorists had to crank their engine by hand.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To turn a crank.
examples: He's been cranking all day and yet it refuses to crank.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, of a crank or similar) To turn.
examples: He's been cranking all day and yet it refuses to crank.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to spin via other means, as though turned by a crank.
examples: I turn the key and crank the engine; yet it doesn't turn over
Crank it up!

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To act in a cranky manner; to behave unreasonably and irritably, especially through complaining.
examples: Quit cranking about your spilt milk!

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be running at a high level of output or effort.
examples: By one hour into the shift, the boys were really cranking.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, dated) To run with a winding course; to double; to crook; to wind and turn.
